notesStmt.note: The O intemerata prayer, added after the end of the final suffrage on fol. 121r, and continuing to fol. 124v, is in a different hand

Extensive birth notes in later hands, mostly in Dutch or Flemish, on fols. 1r-4v, 21v, and 22v; cancelled note on fol. 4v includes the date 1659; notes on fol. 21v includes the dates 1647, 1650, and 1669; note on fol. 22v from 1579; other notes considerably earlier in date
Fol. 6 is severely trimmed along its outer edge

Hirsch, John C., Western Manuscripts of the Twelfth through the Sixteenth Centuries in Lehigh University Libraries: A Guide to the Exhibition (Bethlehem, PA: Rare Book Room, Linderman Library, Lehigh University, 1970), p. 27, no. 15.

msContents.summary: This damaged Book of Hours was likely produced in Northeastern France or Flanders in the late fourteenth century or early fifteenth century. The manuscript begins with a Calendar, which is lacking its first and last months. The book contains the Hours of the Virgin for Franciscan Use, followed by the Hours of the Cross and Hours of the Holy Spirit, the Penitential Psalms followed by a separate section containing the Litany, Prayers, and Collects (beginning lacking), and the Athanasian Creed followed directly by the Obsecro te. The book concludes with Suffrages (fols. 115r-121r), which include Saints Vedast and Eligius, and the O intemerata prayer added in a different hand.

msItem.title: Hours of the Virgin, Franciscan Use
Athanasian Creed followed by Obsecro te
Athanasian Creed followed by Obsecro te
Suffrages, followed by O intemerata added in a different hand

supportDesc.extent: ii+124+ii; 142 x 96 mm bound to 147 x 105 mm

layoutDesc.layout: One column of fourteen lines, ruled in brown ink; written area: 83 x 54 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Large illuminated initials and foliate borders at major text divisions; illuminated initials with foliate sprays at minor divisions; small illuminated initials throughout
Inside front coverBookplate, Robert B. Honeyman

binding.p: Nineteenth-century stamped brown calf, French; "HEURES, MSS. VÈLLIN" stamped on spine

history.provenance: Red bookplate, inside front cover: "Ex Libris Robert Honeyman IV" with shield and banner stating "Progredere ne Regredere"
